alert.note: Alert for Big Horn; Carter; Custer; Fallon; Powder River; Rosebud; Treasure (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 08 at 2:54AM MDT by NWS Billings
info.description: ...Heavy rain mid to late week may lead to flooding... A strong storm system is expected to bring heavy rainfall to the area, starting Wednesday afternoon and continuing through Friday. Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches are likely through the event, with some pockets of 3+ inches possible. This heavy rain will cause rivers and streams to rise aggressively, with flooding possible where rainfall is heaviest. Heavy rain could fall on existing snow in the foothills below 8 thousand feet, which could lead to even faster water rises. Where the heaviest precipitation falls will determine which rivers and streams see the most significant rises. At the moment, areas of Sheridan county Wyoming, including the Bighorn foothills, along with sections of Big Horn county, southern Rosebud county, and western sections of Powder River county, look like the most likely location for the heaviest rainfall, and therefore, the highest possibility of flooding. Rivers and streams in these locations look to be the most susceptible to flooding. Those with interests along area waterways should be prepared for high water levels and move property and livestock away from rivers, streams, and low lying areas. Bank erosion will make shorelines unstable. Do not walk near streambanks as the underlying soil may be eroded. Do not allow children to play near the water`s edge. Heavy precipitation may fill culverts, ditches, and storm drains causing water to flow over roadways, potentially causing damage. Do not drive over flooded roadways, Turn Around Don`t Drown. Recreationists in the mountains and foothills should be prepared for changing conditions and use extra caution when near waterways. Flows will be fast, and the water is cold. Stay tuned to the forecast. Please report any flooding to local law enforcement and have them relay the report to the National Weather Service.
